body.p: The key change introduced by The Grinder 3 is a full scripting engine to define test scripts. This replaces the specification of tests in the grinder.properties file. Most of the other key features of The Grinder 2, such as the console and the process architecture, are unchanged.
Jython is the Java implementation of the Python scripting language. A Jython engine has been introduced into The Grinder to address the following.

blockquote.p: The Grinder 2 is limited in that each worker process executes the tests in the test script sequentially, in a fixed order. The Grinder 3 uses Jython scripts to allow arbitrary branching and looping.

There is very limited support in some of the The Grinder 2 plug-ins for checking the results of tests. The Grinder 3 makes these results directly available to the test script, allowing various test paths to be taken depending on the responses returned by the server.

The Grinder 2 HTTP plug-in's string bean feature provides simple support for requests that contain dynamic data. The Grinder 3 can use the full power of Jython to create dynamic requests of arbitrary complexity.

body.p: Kind of dry, huh? If you never seen any Python or are wondering what was wrong with the old grinder.properties approach then skip ahead the Script Gallery to sample the power of The Grinder 3.
A powerful new "Java" plug-in has been introduced which allows arbitrary Java and Jython code to be tested. This practically removes the need to write custom plug-ins.
A single script can use multiple plug-ins.
The interface that plug-ins must implement has changed significantly. Plug-ins written for The Grinder 2 will not work with The Grinder 3 without significant modification.
The Grinder is distributed in separate binary and source zip files.

ul.li: The HTTP plug-in can now be used through an HTTP proxy.

Many grinder.properties have been removed. The features formally set through properties are now set by making calls to the plug-in from the test script. Some of the remaining property names have been renamed.

body.p: The JUnit and Socket plug-ins have been removed. There functionality can be achieved with the new, more general, Java plug-in.
String beans and OK strings have been removed from the HTTP plug-in. String beans and OK strings are very limited in comparison to to the flexibility now provided by the Jython scripting engine.
The HttpURLConnection implementation has been removed.
